awd_abstract_narration:
This project will promote the progress of science by realizing the untapped innovation potential of female faculty, postdoctoral and other researchers. It will leverage the combination of the already well developed individual resources of the NSF I-Corps program (including the National Innovation Network), and ADVANCE Centers by building mutual understanding of the respective programs, and identifying and initiating synergistic pilot programs to encourage and enable female researchers to realize the translational potential of their research outcomes for positive and societal and economic benefit.  By involving more women in I-Corps through insights developed by ADVANCE, there will be enhanced partnerships between academia and industry and a more diverse American STEM workforce that is globally competitive. 

Goals and Scope: The project brings together participants in two important NSF programs; the Innovation-Corps (I-Corps) and NSF Advance: Organizational Change for Gender Equity in STEM Academic Professions. ADVANCE fosters systemic change that promotes equity for STEM faculty in academic settings, no matter what gender, racial or ethnic backgrounds the STEM faculty participants possess. The I-Corps program prepares participants to extend their focus beyond their university footprint and to accelerate the economic and societal benefits of NSF-funded, basic-research projects that are ready to move toward commercialization. For up to 400 female attendees, this project will create personal and specific connections in the form of local teams developed between ADVANCE Centers and I-Corps Sites/Nodes. While learning best practices from the other they will work to identify and design initiatives to remove barriers and increase accessibility to positive entrepreneurial and innovation outcomes for female researchers. 

Potential contribution: This program will establish and make operational a connection that will enable female STEM participants to extend their focus, ideas and research outcomes beyond their University footprints.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The ADVANCE & I-Corps Joint Program grant began as a conference proposal that sought to bring together two existing National Science Foundation programs:

  • ADVANCE: Organizational Change for Gender Equity in STEM Academic Professions which has a goal to increase the representation and advancement of women in academic science and engineering careers, thereby contributing to the development of a more diverse science and engineering workforce. ADVANCE takes a systemic and intersectional gender equity approach to organizational change to meet this goal and has been in operation since 2001. While ADVANCE grantees have a wealth of knowledge, experience, and expertise around gender equity as well as diversity and inclusion in STEM, grantees often struggle with the sustainability of their efforts beyond the grant funding.

  • Innovation Corps (I-Corps) which prepares scientists and engineers to extend their focus beyond the university laboratory and accelerates the economic and societal benefits of NSF-funded, basic-research projects that are ready to move toward commercialization. I-Corps takes an experiential learning approach to the customer discovery process to support teams in quickly assessing the market potential of their ideas and has been in operation since 2011. While I-Corps programs have rich experience, knowledge, and expertise about funding innovative work, I-Corps grantees face many challenges in addressing equity, diversity, and inclusion (EDI) issues in their efforts.

The intent of the 2019 Joint Summit, hosted as part of the ADVANCE Equity in STEM Community Convening, was to leverage the collective and complementary resources of both of these programs by building mutual understanding of the respective programs and identifying and initiating synergistic collaborative pilot projects to sustainably address EDI challenges.

At the Summit, the project team organized tables regionally and interspersed ADVANCE and I-Corps grantees. Throughout the day, attendees participated in Strategic Doing activities and heard from panelists with expertise in addressing EDI issues in I-Corps and sustaining their ADVANCE work. Collaborative groups resulted from the meeting and left with action plans for working together on projects initiated at the Summit. The project team followed up with these collaborative groups every 30-45 days for the next six months.

Based on the activities that were successful compared to those that fizzled out, the project team identified a common pain point for further exploration. Many I-Corps practitioners knew that EDI practices were important and necessary, but did not have the insight needed, budget available to hire their ADVANCE collaborators, or even the time to do the in-depth assessment necessary for identifying specific areas in need of improvement and develop and deliver solutions that would result in change.

After identifying this pain point, the project team developed a platform-as-a-service and process called Inclusive Innovation that would a) provide I-Corps programs with site-specific assessments about their assets and opportunities for growth; b) receive and act on a customized recommendation roadmap for improving EDI practices in all parts of the organization; c) support individual and team behavioral change through education as well as ongoing, democratized feedback and self-reflection; and d) hold programs accountable and provide implementation consultation by a group of EDI experts from the ADVANCE and I-Corps communities. The Inclusive Innovation tool and process was successfully piloted and implemented with five I-Corps locations during the funding period.

 


Last Modified: 04/17/2023
Modified by: Heather Metcalf

The ADVANCE & I-Corps Joint Program grant began as a conference proposal that sought to bring together two existing National Science Foundation programs:

 ADVANCE: Organizational Change for Gender Equity in STEM Academic Professions which has a goal to increase the representation and advancement of women in academic science and engineering careers, thereby contributing to the development of a more diverse science and engineering workforce. I-Corps takes an experiential learning approach to the customer discovery process to support teams in quickly assessing the market potential of their ideas and has been in operation since 2011.
